No, the full Rs 100,000 will not be settled. For cataract treatment, the maximum payable is 25% of the Sum Insured or Rs 40,000 per eye, whichever is lower, per policy period. Any amount above this limit will not be reimbursed.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer for the same hospitalization if the full claim has already been settled and approved by HDFC. Health insurance policies do not allow double compensation for the same expenses. You can only claim up to the actual expenses incurred, and once the claim is settled by one insurer, the same expenses cannot be claimed again from another insurer.

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of these rights except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that protects individuals against arbitrary actions by the state and has been interpreted to include a wide range of rights such as the right to privacy, right to a fair trial, right to livelihood, and right to a clean environment.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above), including in matters of admission to educational institutions and reservation in services under the State.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it will be a case of theft under criminal law.

Yes, you can be arrested without a warrant if the arrest is made according to procedure established by law. However, you must be informed of the grounds for your arrest, have the right to consult a legal practitioner of your choice, and be produced before the nearest magistrate within twenty-four hours of arrest, excluding travel time. Detention beyond this period requires the authority of a magistrate.
No, denying you a job because of your caste is not allowed. Discrimination in employment under the State on grounds of caste is prohibited.

You cannot stop the government from acquiring your land for a public purpose if the acquisition is done in accordance with the law in force. However, if the land is under your personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit, the State cannot acquire it unless compensation at not less than market value is provided for the land, building, or structure.
No, it is not legal. No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.
Yes, stopping you from speaking at a protest is against your right to freedom of speech and expression as guaranteed to all citizens.

If a religious place stops you from entering because you are a woman, it may be constitutional if the restriction is based on the right of a religious denomination to manage its own affairs under Article 26, subject to public order, morality, and health. However, general discrimination by the State on grounds of sex is prohibited under Article 15(2). If the religious place is a private religious institution and not a State entity, such restrictions may be allowed under Article 26 and Article 25(2), but if it is a State-managed institution, such discrimination would not be constitutional.

No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. The right to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion are guaranteed, subject only to public order, morality, and health.
The right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty, as no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

No, you cannot be denied admission to a public university solely because you are from a backward community. The Constitution prohibits denial of admission on grounds only of religion, race, caste, or language. In fact, the State is permitted to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including reservations or preferences in admissions. If you are denied admission solely for being from a backward community, you can challenge this action as it violates your constitutional rights.

questions: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
According to Newton, what are the three laws of motion and how do they apply in celestial mechanics?
How does Newton derive Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) from his laws of motion and gravitation?
How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
What mathematical tools did Newton use in Principia that were precursors to calculus, and why didn't he use standard calculus notation?
How does Newton use the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion?
How does Newton handle motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids?
In what way does Newton's notion of absolute space and time differ from relative motion, and how does it support his laws?
Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?
Do we know any other descent of Isaac Newton apart from his grandfather?
answers:
Newton defines 'quantity of motion' as the measure arising from the velocity (celerity) multiplied by the quantity of matter (mass). It is the sum of the motions of all the parts of a body, so for a body with double the mass at equal velocity, the quantity of motion is double; with twice the velocity, it is quadruple.

'Force' is distinct from 'quantity of motion' in that motive force arises from the accelerative force multiplied by the quantity of matter. While quantity of motion depends on mass and velocity, force depends on mass and acceleration.

Newton’s three laws of motion are:

1. First Law (Law of Inertia): An object remains at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.
2. Second Law (Law of Acceleration): The force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by its acceleration (F = ma).
3. Third Law (Action-Reaction): For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

In celestial mechanics, these laws explain planetary motion, orbital dynamics, and gravitational interactions. The first law describes how planets move in stable orbits unless influenced by external forces. The second law quantifies how gravitational force causes acceleration of celestial bodies. The third law governs mutual gravitational attraction, ensuring that forces between two bodies, such as a planet and the Sun, are equal and opposite.

Newton derives Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) using his laws of motion and universal gravitation by showing that a planet orbiting the Sun experiences a central force directed toward the Sun (gravity). This central force produces zero torque about the Sun, so the planet's angular momentum is conserved. Conservation of angular momentum means the line joining the planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal times, which is Kepler's Second Law.

Newton demonstrates that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses by showing that the force of gravity towards each particle of a body is reciprocally as the square of the distance from that particle. When considering two spheres with similar matter distributed equidistantly from their centers, the gravitational force between them is inversely as the square of the distance between their centers. This relationship is confirmed by observing the motions of celestial bodies, such as moons orbiting planets, which follow Kepler’s laws and thus require a centripetal force that varies inversely with the square of the distance from the center. Newton further explains that the total gravitational force from a planet is the sum of the forces from all its parts, each following the inverse square law, and this law holds accurately at large distances and nearly so near the planet’s surface.

Gravitational force must act on all masses universally because experiments and astronomical observations show that all bodies gravitate toward each other in proportion to the quantity of matter they contain. The moon gravitates toward the earth, the sea gravitates toward the moon, all planets mutually gravitate toward one another, and comets gravitate toward the sun. The force of gravity between any two bodies is proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers. This universal gravitation applies to every particle of matter, establishing that all bodies are endowed with a principle of mutual gravitation.

Newton explains the perturbation of planetary orbits as the result of gravitational forces exerted by other planets. These mutual gravitational attractions cause deviations from perfect elliptical orbits, leading to changes in orbital elements such as eccentricity, inclination, and orientation. The superposition of these forces results in complex, time-dependent variations in each planet’s trajectory, known as orbital perturbations.

Newton used geometric methods and his fluxionary calculus as mathematical tools in Principia, which were precursors to calculus. He did not use standard calculus notation because he admired the taste and form of demonstration of the ancients, preferring geometric proofs, and he regretted not following their style more closely. Additionally, he was reluctant to publish his purely mathematical writings due to his repugnance to contest or dispute.

Newton explains orbital motion by stating that a centripetal force acts continuously on a body moving in a curved path, such as a planet orbiting the Sun. This centripetal force is always directed toward the center of the orbit, causing the body to accelerate toward that center and thus maintain its curved trajectory. In planetary motion, gravity provides the necessary centripetal force, keeping planets in stable orbits around the Sun.

Newton explains that the resistance experienced by bodies moving in fluids is nearly proportional to the density of the fluid and the square of the velocity of the body. He distinguishes between different types of resistance—arising from the inactivity of the fluid, the tenacity of its parts, or friction. In sufficiently fluid media like air, water, and certain oils, resistance is mainly proportional to density. He also notes that more tenacious fluids resist more than less viscous ones of equal density. Newton provides methods to determine the density of the medium and the resistance encountered by a body moving along a given curve, and confirms his theory with experiments, such as those involving pendulums.

Newton's notion of absolute space and time asserts that space and time exist independently and uniformly, providing a fixed, unchanging reference frame. Absolute space is the same everywhere and does not depend on the position or motion of objects, while absolute time flows uniformly regardless of events. In contrast, relative motion describes the movement of objects only in relation to each other, not to any fixed background.

Newton's laws, especially the first law (law of inertia), require a fixed reference frame to define true motion and rest. Absolute space and time provide this universal frame, allowing Newton to distinguish between true motion (relative to absolute space) and apparent motion (relative to other objects). This distinction is essential for formulating and applying his laws of motion consistently.
Isaac Newton's grandfather was Robert Newton.
No, Isaac Newton did not have any descendants. He never married and had no children, so he left no direct lineage.

Based on the provided policy document, here is the process and potential reasons for refusal for adding a newly-adopted 3-year-old child:

### **Process for Adding the Child**

The policyholder must submit a written request to add the child. The child is eligible for coverage under the following conditions:

*   **Eligibility by Age:** The child, being 3 years old, falls within the eligible age bracket of 91 days to 18 years.
*   **Parental Coverage:** A parent must be concurrently covered under the policy for the child to be eligible.
*   **Premium Payment:** A prorated premium will be charged for the new dependent from the date of addition until the policy expires.

### **Circumstances for Refusal of Cover**

The insurer may refuse to cover the child under the following circumstances:

1.  **Ineligibility:** If the parent (the employee/member) is not concurrently covered under the policy.
2.  **Non-disclosure or Fraud:** If the policyholder commits fraud, misrepresentation, or fails to disclose any material fact regarding the child.
3.  **Procedural Lapses:** The policy specifies a 30-day window from the inception date for additions. While not explicitly stated for adoption, a request made outside a contractually defined period for life events may be refused.

Based on the policy terms, the newborn's intensive care treatment expenses are eligible for a claim.

Here is the breakdown based on the provided document:

*   **Newborn Coverage:** The policy explicitly states under "Other Special Condition Details" that the "Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured" (Page 4). This means the newborn is considered an insured person from the moment of birth.
*   **Eligibility:** The conditions for this coverage, as per the "Eligibility" clause (Page 27), are that the mother is covered and maternity cover is opted for, which is the case in this scenario.
*   **Definition:** The infant qualifies as a "New Born Baby," which is defined as a "baby born during the Policy period and is aged up to 90 days" (Page 19).
*   **Exclusions:** While the policy excludes "Medical treatment expenses traceable to child birth" (Page 25), this typically refers to the standard costs of the delivery procedure itself, which are covered under the mother's separate Maternity Benefit. The newborn's need for separate intensive care is a distinct medical event for a newly insured person and is therefore not subject to this exclusion.

Therefore, the costs for the intensive care the newborn received before expiring are admissible for a claim under the family's sum insured.

Here is the justification based on the policy document:

1.  **Eligible Practitioners for Claim Documentation:** According to the claim procedure for reimbursement (Clause VI.A.5.i.iv), the claim must be supported by an "Attending **medical practitioner's / surgeon's** certificate regarding diagnosis".
2.  **Definition of "Medical Practitioner":** The policy defines a "Medical Practitioner" (Clause II.A.26) as a person with a valid registration from the Medical Council of India or equivalent, which includes a General Practitioner and a Psychiatrist.
3.  **Definition of "Clinical Psychologist":** A "Clinical Psychologist" is defined under "Mental Healthcare Professional" (Clause II.B.27) but is not classified as a "Medical Practitioner" or "Surgeon".

Therefore, while a General Practitioner's prescription is valid, the discharge summary and diagnostic certificate for an inpatient psychiatric claim must be from the attending **Medical Practitioner** (in this case, a **Psychiatrist**), not a Clinical Psychologist, to be considered sufficient for claim processing.

Based on the policy document, here is the course of action:

1.  **Document Deficiency and Resubmission:**
    *   The TPA/Insurer will scrutinize the claim and inform the insured of any missing documents.
    *   The insured has 10 working days from the first intimation to provide the necessary documents. The insurer will send a maximum of three reminders.

2.  **Claim Rejection Timeline:**
    *   After receiving the final necessary documents, the company must settle or reject the claim within 15 days.
    *   If the claim is rejected, the company will communicate the grounds for rejection in writing.

3.  **Contesting the Final Rejection:**
    *   **Step 1: Reconsideration:** The insured person may, within 15 days of receiving the rejection, request that the insurer reconsider the decision.
    *   **Step 2: Grievance Redressal:** If still unsatisfied, the insured can contact the company's grievance redressal channels:
        *   **Website:** www.uiic.co.in
        *   **Toll free:** 1800 425 333 33
        *   **E-mail:** customercare@uiic.co.in
        *   **Courier:** Customer Care Department, Head Office, United India Insurance Co. Ltd., 24, Whites Road, Chennai, Tamil Nadu- 600014
    *   **Step 3: Grievance Officer:** If the issue persists, the insured may contact the grievance officer at customercare@uiic.co.in.
    *   **Step 4: External Authorities:** If still not satisfied, the insured can approach the **Insurance Ombudsman** of the respective region or lodge a grievance at the **IRDAI Integrated Grievance Management System (IGMS)** at https://igms.irda.gov.in/.

Finally, if a claim is rejected and not pursued through a pending suit within twelve months from the date of rejection, it is considered abandoned, and the insurer's liability is extinguished.

ii. which would have otherwise required a hospitalisation of more than 24 hours.

For a hospital to qualify under this policy, it must meet several minimum criteria. The requirements that differ based on population are:

*   **In towns with a population of less than 10,00,000 (1 million):** The hospital must have at least 10 in-patient beds.
*   **In all other places (including metropolitan areas):** The hospital must have at least 15 in-patient beds.

Additionally, all qualifying hospitals, regardless of location, must meet the following infrastructure and service requirements:
*   Has qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock.
*   Has qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock.
*   Has a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out.
*   Maintains daily records of patients and makes these accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.

Based on the policy document, here are the eligibility criteria and documentation process for adding a new employee, their spouse, and sibling:

### **Eligibility Criteria**

*   **New Employee:** Must be a newly appointed employee of the policyholder.
*   **Spouse:** Must be the employee's legal spouse.
*   **Sibling:** Must be the employee's sibling, up to the age of 26 years, and must be unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.

### **Process and Documentation**

The policyholder must provide written notification to the insurer with the details of the eligible persons to be added. The addition is subject to the following conditions:
1.  The insurer accepts the application for cover.
2.  An additional premium is paid on a pro-rata basis for the remaining policy duration.
3.  The insurer issues a written endorsement confirming the addition.

The policy specifies that for any endorsement, "additional information/documents/ premium may be requested" by the underwriter as part of the assessment.

For an air ambulance evacuation necessitated by an accident, the following steps and documentation are required:

### **Mandatory Pre-authorization Steps**

In the event of an emergency requiring air ambulance evacuation, you must follow these steps for pre-authorization:

1.  **Immediate Notification:** The Insured Person or their representative must notify the insurer immediately, either at their call center or in writing.
2.  **Mandatory Pre-authorization:** All emergency medical evacuations must be pre-authorized by the insurer.
3.  **Medical Necessity Assessment:** The insurer's team of specialists, in association with the emergency assistance service provider, will determine the medical necessity of the evacuation and repatriation. The evacuation will only be approved after this assessment is complete.

### **Required Documents for Claims Assessment**

For the claim to be assessed and reimbursed, you must submit the following documents:

Based on the policy terms, the expense for an imported medication not normally used in India is unlikely to be covered. The policy contains several clauses that would likely lead to the denial of such a claim.

Relevant clauses include:

*   **Medically Necessary Treatment (Clause II.A.27):** For a treatment to be covered, it must, among other criteria, "conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India" and must not be "experimental, investigational or for research purposes." An imported drug not standard in India could be deemed experimental or not conforming to accepted standards.

*   **Unproven Treatments (Clause IV.B.16, Code-Excl16):** The policy excludes "Expenses related to any unproven treatment, services and supplies... Unproven treatments are treatments, procedures or supplies that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness." The insurer could classify a non-standard imported drug as unproven.

*   **Specific Exclusions (Clause IV.C.7):** The policy excludes "Any treatment or part of a treatment that... is not a Medically Necessary Treatment." This directly links back to the definition above, reinforcing that if the medication is not considered medically necessary by the insurer's standards, it will not be covered.

Based on the policy's definitions and exclusions, prostheses or medical appliances are not covered in the following scenarios, even if associated with hospitalization:

1.  **When not required intra-operatively:** Prostheses, corrective devices, and/or Medical Appliances that are not required *during* the surgical procedure for the illness or injury are excluded.
2.  **For routine vision or hearing correction:** The cost of spectacles, multifocal lenses, contact lenses, and hearing aids are not covered.
3.  **For external use during or after treatment:** The policy excludes instruments like a C.P.A.P. machine for Sleep Apnea, an Oxygen Concentrator for Bronchial Asthma, an infusion pump, or any other external devices used during or after treatment.
4.  **For convenience or home use:** Non-medical expenses are excluded, which include a wide range of items for personal comfort or home use, such as:
    *   Ambulatory devices (walkers, crutches)
    *   Belts, collars, splints, slings, braces, stockings
    *   Diabetic footwear
    *   Glucometers or thermometers
    *   Any medical equipment subsequently used at home (unless it forms part of the room expenses).

This benefit is payable if an Insured Person is diagnosed with one of the 11 specified critical illnesses, including cancer, and a claim is admissible. The benefit is paid once per disease during the person's lifetime and is based on the survival period after discharge from the hospital.

The payable amounts are as follows:

    *   For a policy with 25% of Sum Insured coverage: **10% of the Sum Insured**

    *   For a policy with 15% of Sum Insured coverage: **10% of the Sum Insured**
    *   For a policy with 25% of Sum Insured coverage: **15% of the Sum Insured**

questions: What types of hospitalization expenses are covered, and what are the limits for room and room expenses?
What is domiciliary hospitalization, and what are its key exclusions?
What are the benefits and limits of telemedicine and maternity coverage under this policy?
What specialized treatments are covered, and what are their sub-limits?
What are the waiting periods for pre-existing diseases and specified diseases or procedures?
answers: Based on the policy, the following hospitalization expenses are covered: * **Medical and Surgical Treatment:** Coverage for medical and surgical treatments in registered hospitals and nursing homes, based on the advice of a qualified medical practitioner. * **Specific Medical Fees:** This includes fees for the surgeon, anesthetist, consultant, and specialist, as well as charges for anesthesia, blood, oxygen, operation theater, and medicines. The limit for room and nursing expenses is up to 1% of the sum insured or ₹5,000 daily. ICU expenses are also covered.

Domiciliary hospitalization provides home treatment coverage for a minimum of three days when hospital admission is not feasible, either because the patient's condition prevents transfer or due to the unavailability of a hospital room. The key exclusions for domiciliary hospitalization are: * Pre post hospitalization expenses excluded * Asthma diabetes hypertension specific diseases * Coverage limit specified policy schedule

Based on the policy document, here are the benefits and limits for telemedicine and maternity coverage: **Telemedicine Coverage:** * Covers digital consultation expenses with registered medical practitioners via telecommunication platforms. * Registered practitioner consultation expenses are covered. * There is a ₹2,000 limit per insured family. * The coverage is limited per policy period. **Maternity Benefits:** * This is an optional coverage available for a 10% additional premium. * Coverage of ₹50,000 is provided for the first two children. * A nine-month waiting period is required. * The newborn is covered from day one for one month.

Based on the document, the specialized medical coverage areas and their sub-limits are: * **HIV/AIDS:** Comprehensive coverage including acute infection, clinical latency, and AIDS-related medical treatment expenses. * **Mental Illness:** Hospitalization in mental health establishments, excluding substance abuse and mental retardation therapies. * **Advanced Procedures:** * Uterine Artery Embolization * Robotic Surgeries: ₹50,000 * Oral Chemotherapy: ₹1,00,000 * 25% coverage

Based on the document, the waiting periods are as follows: * **Pre-existing Diseases:** A 36-month waiting period applies to all pre-existing medical conditions before coverage becomes effective. * **Specified Diseases/Procedures:** A waiting period of 1-3 years applies to specific conditions like hernia, cataract, and joint replacement procedures.

questions: What types of hospitalization expenses are covered, and what are the limits for room and ICU expenses?
What is domiciliary hospitalization, and what are its key exclusions?
What are the benefits and limits of Ambulance Services?
What are the benefits and limits of telemedicine and maternity coverage under this policy?
What are the waiting periods for pre-existing diseases and specified diseases or procedures?
answers:
Based on the document, the following reasonable and customary hospitalization expenses are reimbursable:

*   **Room, Boarding, and Nursing Expenses:** Limited to 1% of the Sum Insured or Rs. 5,000 per day, whichever is less.
*   **I.C.U. (Intensive Care Unit) Expenses:** Limited to 2% of the Sum Insured or Rs. 10,000 per day, whichever is less.
*   **Fees:** For Surgeons, Anaesthetists, Medical Practitioners, Consultants, and Specialists.
*   **Other Charges:** Anaesthesia, Blood, Oxygen, Operation Theatre Charges, Surgical Appliances, Medicines & Drugs, Dialysis, Chemotherapy, Radiotherapy, Artificial Limbs, cost of implanted prosthetic devices (like pacemakers), relevant laboratory/diagnostic tests, and X-rays.
*   **Ambulance Services:** 1% of the sum insured or Rs. 2,000, whichever is less, for shifting the patient from residence to hospital for emergency/ICU admission or from one hospital to another for better facilities.

Based on the document, domiciliary hospitalization is medical treatment for an illness, disease, or injury that lasts for more than three days. This treatment would normally require hospital care but is instead taken at home under one of the following circumstances:
*   The patient's condition prevents them from being moved to a hospital.
*   A room is not available in a hospital.

The key exclusions for Domiciliary Hospitalisation benefit are:
1.  Expenses for pre and post-hospital treatment.
2.  Expenses for treatment of the following diseases:
    *   Asthma
    *   Bronchitis
    *   Chronic Nephritis and Nephritic Syndrome
    *   Diarrhoea and all types of Dysenteries, including Gastro-enteritis
    *   Diabetes Mellitus and Insipidus
    *   Epilepsy
    *   Hypertension
    *   Influenza, Cough and Cold
    *   Pyrexia of unknown origin for less than 10 days
    *   Tonsillitis and Upper Respiratory Tract infection, including Laryngitis and Pharyngitis
    *   Arthritis, Gout, and Rheumatism

Ambulance services are reimbursable up to 1% of the sum insured or Rs. 2,000/-, whichever is less.

This benefit is applicable when a patient is shifted by a registered ambulance in the following cases:
*   From their residence to a hospital for admission into an Emergency Ward or I.C.U.
*   From one Hospital/Nursing home to another for better medical facilities.

Based on the document, here are the benefits and limits for telemedicine and maternity coverage:

**Telemedicine (Clause 2B):**
*   **Benefit:** Reimburses expenses for teleconsultation with a registered medical practitioner for the diagnosis and treatment of a disease or illness covered by the policy.
*   **Limit:** Maximum of Rs. 2,000 per insured and/or per family for a policy period.

**Maternity Expenses and Newborn Child Cover (Clause 2C):**
This is an optional benefit extension with the following conditions:
*   **Benefit:** Covers maternity expenses and newborn child care. A newborn child is covered from day one up to the age of 3 months for in-patient hospital treatment.
*   **Cost:** Requires an additional payment of 10% of the total basic premium.
*   **Eligibility:** Not available to those who already have two or more living children. Claims are only considered for the first two children.
*   **Limit:** The maximum benefit is up to Rs. 50,000, which is part of the basic sum insured.
*   **Waiting Period:** A 9-month waiting period applies to claims for normal delivery, caesarean section, or abdominal operations for extra-uterine pregnancy.
*   **Exclusions:**
    *   Voluntary medical termination of pregnancy during the first 12 weeks.
    *   Pre-natal and post-natal expenses, unless admitted to a hospital for treatment.
    *   Pre-hospitalization and post-hospitalization benefits are not available under this extension.

Based on the document, the waiting periods are as follows:

**1. Pre-existing Diseases (PED):**
*   Expenses for treating a pre-existing disease and its complications are excluded for **36 months** of continuous coverage from the first policy's inception date.

**2. Specified Diseases/Procedures:**
There are specific waiting periods for the following conditions:
*   **90 Days:**
    *   Hypertension
    *   Diabetes
*   **1 Year:**
    *   Benign ENT disorders (e.g., Tonsillectomy, Adenoidectomy)
    *   Polycystic ovarian diseases
*   **2 Years:**
    *   Surgery of hernia
    *   Surgery of hydrocele
    *   Non-infective Arthritis
    *   Undescended Testes
    *   Cataract
    *   Surgery of benign prostatic hypertrophy
    *   Hysterectomy for menorrhagia, fibromyoma, or prolapse of uterus
    *   Fissure / Fistula in anus
    *   Piles
    *   Sinusitis and related disorders
    *   Surgery of gallbladder and bile duct (excluding malignancy)
    *   Surgery of genito-urinary system (excluding malignancy)
    *   Pilonidal Sinus
    *   Gout and Rheumatism
    *   Calculus diseases
    *   Surgery for prolapsed inter vertebral disk (unless from an accident)
    *   Surgery of varicose veins and varicose ulcers
*   **3 Years:**
    *   Joint Replacement due to Degenerative condition
    *   Age-related osteoarthritis and Osteoporosis

**3. General 30-Day Waiting Period:**
*   Expenses for any illness within the first **30 days** of the policy are excluded, except for claims arising from an accident. This does not apply if the insured has had continuous coverage for more than twelve months.

**2. Claiming from Other Policies if Sum Insured is Exhausted:**

Yes, if the amount to be claimed exceeds the sum insured under a single policy, you have the right to choose another insurer from whom you want to claim the balance amount. The policy states (Clause 5.22) that an insured person with multiple policies can prefer claims under this policy for amounts disallowed under other policies, even if the sum insured is not exhausted. The insurer you choose first will be the primary insurer and will coordinate with other insurers to settle the balance amount.

**3. Nominating a New Legal Heir:**

You can change the nomination at any time during the policy term. To do so, you must communicate the change to the company in writing. The new nomination will only be effective after an endorsement is made on the policy. In the event of the policyholder's death without a nominee, the company will pay the claim to the legal heirs or legal representatives of the policyholder (Clause 5.14).

### **Cashless Psychiatric Care for a Dependent Child**

Coverage for inpatient psychiatric care for a dependent child is available under the Mental Illness Cover (Section 3.1.14). To avail this on a cashless basis at "Harmony Wellness," the following conditions must be met:

*   **Network Hospital:** "Harmony Wellness" must be a "Mental Health Establishment" as defined in the policy and part of the insurer's network of hospitals.

*   **Dependent Child:** The policy covers dependent children from 91 days up to 18 years. A male child can be covered up to 25 years if he is a financially dependent student, and a female child is covered until she gets married.

### **Life Hardship Survival Benefit for Critical Illness**

If an Insured Person is diagnosed with one of the 11 specified critical illnesses, including cancer, a survival benefit is payable after hospital discharge. This benefit is paid only once per disease during the insured's lifetime and is not applicable for illnesses existing at the time of policy inception.

The payable amount depends on the survival period, as detailed below:

| Total amount payable | Amount payable on survival for 180 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (the first discharge date when more than one Hospitalization is involved). | Amount payable on survival for 270 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (the first discharge date when more than one Hospitalization is involved). |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **15% of Sum Insured under the Policy** | 5% of the Sum Insured | 10% of the Sum Insured |
| **25% of Sum Insured under the Policy** | 10% of the Sum Insured | 15% of the Sum Insured |

*   **Pre-existing Diseases (PED) waiting period:** Expenses for any pre-existing disease and its complications are not covered until after 36 months of continuous coverage (as per clause 4.1).

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that protects individuals against arbitrary actions of the state and has been interpreted to include a wide range of rights such as the right to privacy, right to a fair trial, right to livelihood, and right to a clean environment.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above) under Article 15.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it will be a case of theft under criminal law.

Yes, you can be arrested without a warrant if the arrest is made according to the procedure established by law. However, after arrest, you must be informed of the grounds for arrest, allowed to consult a legal practitioner of your choice, and produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time. Detention beyond this period requires the authority of a magistrate.
No, denying you a job because of your caste is not allowed. Discrimination in employment under the State on grounds only of caste is prohibited.

You cannot stop the government from acquiring your land for a public purpose if the acquisition is done in accordance with the law in force. However, if the land is under your personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit, the State cannot acquire it unless compensation at not less than market value is provided for the land, building, or structure.

No, it is not legal. No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment. Forcing a child to work in such conditions is prohibited and punishable by law.
Yes, stopping you from speaking at a protest is against your right to freedom of speech and expression as guaranteed to all citizens.
No, it is not constitutional. Denying entry to a religious place solely on the ground of sex violates the right to equality and non-discrimination guaranteed under the Constitution of India.

No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. The right to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion is guaranteed, subject only to public order, morality, and health.
The right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty under Article 21 of the Constitution of India.

You cannot be denied admission to a public university solely because you are from a socially and educationally backward community. The Constitution prohibits denial of admission on grounds only of religion, race, caste, or language. In fact, the State is permitted to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including reservation in admissions. If you are denied admission solely on the basis of being from a backward community, you can challenge this action as it violates your constitutional rights.

questions: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
According to Newton, what are the three laws of motion and how do they apply in celestial mechanics?
How does Newton derive Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) from his laws of motion and gravitation?
How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
What mathematical tools did Newton use in Principia that were precursors to calculus, and why didn't he use standard calculus notation?
How does Newton use the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion?
How does Newton handle motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids?
In what way does Newton's notion of absolute space and time differ from relative motion, and how does it support his laws?
Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?
Do we know any other descent of Isaac Newton apart from his grandfather?
answers:
Newton defines 'quantity of motion' as the measure arising from the velocity (celerity) multiplied by the quantity of matter (mass). It is the sum of the motions of all the parts of a body, so in a body with double the mass and equal velocity, the quantity of motion is double; with twice the velocity, it is quadruple.

'Force' is distinct from 'quantity of motion' in that motive force arises from the accelerative force multiplied by the quantity of matter. While quantity of motion depends on mass and velocity, force depends on mass and acceleration.

Newton’s three laws of motion are:

1. First Law (Law of Inertia): An object remains at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.
2. Second Law (Law of Acceleration): The force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by its acceleration (F = ma).
3. Third Law (Action-Reaction Law): For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

In celestial mechanics, these laws explain planetary motion, orbital dynamics, and gravitational interactions. The first law describes how planets move in stable orbits unless influenced by external forces. The second law quantifies the effect of gravitational force on planetary acceleration. The third law governs mutual gravitational attraction between celestial bodies, ensuring that forces between them are equal and opposite.

Newton derives Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) using his laws of motion and universal gravitation by showing that a planet orbiting the Sun experiences a central force directed toward the Sun. This central force causes the planet's angular momentum to be conserved. Conservation of angular momentum means that the line joining the planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal intervals of time, which is Kepler's Second Law. The key concepts are central force, conservation of angular momentum, and the area law.

Newton demonstrates that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses by showing that the force of gravity towards each particle of a body is reciprocally as the square of the distance from that particle. When considering two spheres with similar matter distributed equidistantly from their centers, the gravitational force between them is inversely as the square of the distance between their centers. This relationship is confirmed by observing the motions of celestial bodies, such as moons orbiting planets, which follow Kepler’s laws and thus require a centripetal force that varies inversely with the square of the distance from the center. Newton further explains that the total gravitational force from a planet is the sum of the forces from all its parts, each following the inverse square law, and this holds true both at large distances and near the planet’s surface.

Gravitational force must act on all masses universally because experiments and astronomical observations show that all bodies gravitate towards each other in proportion to the quantity of matter they contain. This mutual gravitation is observed between the earth and objects near it, between the earth and the moon, between the sea and the moon, among all the planets, and between comets and the sun. The force of gravity between any two bodies is proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers. Therefore, every particle of matter attracts every other particle, establishing the principle of universal gravitation.

Newton explains the perturbation of planetary orbits as the result of gravitational forces exerted by other planets. These mutual gravitational attractions cause deviations from perfect elliptical orbits, leading to irregularities such as changes in orbital speed, direction, and position. The superposition of these forces results in complex, non-Keplerian motion, known as orbital perturbations.

Newton used geometric methods and the concept of "fluxions" (his term for derivatives) as mathematical tools in Principia, which were precursors to calculus. He did not use standard calculus notation because he preferred the style and rigor of classical geometry, admired the ancient mathematicians' methods, and was reluctant to publish his purely mathematical writings due to his aversion to controversy and disputes.

Newton explains orbital motion by stating that a centripetal force acts continuously on a body moving in a curved path, such as a planet orbiting the Sun. This force is always directed toward the center of the orbit, causing the body to accelerate toward that center and thus maintain its curved trajectory. In planetary motion, gravity provides the necessary centripetal force, keeping planets in stable orbits around the Sun.

Newton explains that the resistance experienced by bodies moving in fluids is nearly proportional to the density of the fluid and the square of the velocity of the body. He notes that lighter fluids like air offer less resistance than denser ones like water or mercury, in direct proportion to their densities. The resistance in fluids arises from three factors: the inactivity of the fluid matter, the tenacity of its parts, and friction. For sufficiently fluid substances, resistance is mainly determined by density and velocity squared. Newton also distinguishes that more viscous fluids resist more than less viscous ones, even if their densities are equal. He analyzes the resistance mathematically and confirms his theory with experiments, such as those involving pendulums.

Newton's notion of absolute space and time asserts that space and time exist independently and uniformly, providing a fixed, unchanging framework. Absolute space is the same everywhere and does not depend on the presence or motion of objects; absolute time flows uniformly without relation to anything external. In contrast, relative motion refers to the movement of objects only in relation to each other or to a chosen reference frame. Newton's absolute space and time support his laws by providing a universal reference for defining true motion, acceleration, and force, ensuring that his laws of motion and universal gravitation apply consistently regardless of the observer's state of motion.
Isaac Newton's grandfather was Robert Newton.
No, Isaac Newton did not have any descendants. He never married and had no children, so he left no direct lineage.

questions: What is the grace period for premium payment?
Are the medical expenses for an organ donor covered under this policy?
answers: The Grace Period for payment of the premium is thirty days. This is the specified period of time immediately following the premium due date during which a premium payment can be made to renew or continue a policy in force without loss of continuity benefits. However, coverage is not available during the period for which no premium is received.

Yes, the policy covers the medical expenses for an organ donor's hospitalization for the harvesting of the organ, provided certain conditions are met.

Under Section 3.1.7, "Organ Donor's Hospitalisation Expenses," the company will cover these expenses provided that:
i. The organ donation confirms to the Transplantation of Human Organs Act 1994 (and its amendments from time to time)
ii. The organ is used for an Insured Person and the Insured Person has been medically advised to undergo an organ transplant
iii. The Medical Expenses shall be incurred in respect of the organ donor as an in-patient in a Hospital.
iv. Claim has been admitted under In-patient Treatment Section in respect of the Insured Person undergoing the organ transplant.

However, there are specific exclusions for this coverage:
i. Pre-hospitalization Medical Expenses or Post- Hospitalization Medical Expenses of the organ donor.
ii. Costs directly or indirectly associated with the acquisition of the donor's organ.
iii. Medical Expenses where the organ transplant is experimental or investigational.
iv. Any medical treatment or complication in respect of the donor, consequent to harvesting.
v. Any expenses related to organ transportation or preservation.

Based on the policy terms, here is the payability of the items:

Based on the provided policy document, here is how the respective expenses are limited:

*   **Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM):** Expenses are covered "up to the limit as specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance per policy period for claims involving Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring."

*   **ICU Care:** The expense for ICU accommodation is limited to **4% of the Sum Insured (SI)**, which is inclusive of nursing charges. The policy does not specify different limits based on city population.

*   **Critical Care Definitions:**
    *   **Intensive Care Unit:** An identified section, ward or wing of a hospital which is under the constant supervision of a dedicated medical practitioner(s), and which is specially equipped for the continuous monitoring and treatment of patients who are in a critical condition, or require life support facilities and where the level of care and supervision is considerably more sophisticated and intensive than in the ordinary and other wards.
    *   **ICU Charges:** The amount charged by a Hospital towards ICU expenses which shall include the expenses for ICU bed, general medical support services provided to any ICU patient including monitoring devices, critical care nursing and intensivist charges.

Based on the policy's eligibility and addition clauses, the process to add a newly-adopted child is as follows:

The policyholder must submit a written application to the insurer to add the child. If the application is accepted, the policyholder must pay an additional premium on a pro-rata basis for the remainder of the policy period. The insurer will then issue a written endorsement confirming the child's addition to the policy.

The insurer may refuse to cover the child under the following circumstances:

*   **Eligibility:** The child, who is between 91 days and 18 years old, can only be covered if at least one parent is concurrently covered under the policy. If the parent is not covered, the child is not eligible.
*   **Addition Process:** The policy's "Additions" clause specifically lists "Newly appointed employee," "Newly wedded spouse," and "New born child" as categories for mid-term additions. Since an adopted child does not fall into these specific categories, the insurer may refuse a mid-term addition and require the policyholder to wait until the policy renewal period to add the child.
*   **Procedural Failure:** The insurer can refuse if the policyholder fails to pay the required additional pro-rata premium or does not complete the necessary application for the endorsement.

Based on the policy terms, the newborn's treatment expenses are eligible for a claim.

The "Other Special Condition Details" on page 4 explicitly state, "**Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured**." This provision ensures that medical expenses incurred for the newborn, including intensive care, are covered from the moment of birth under the family's total sum insured.

The policy defines a "New Born Baby" as a baby aged up to 90 days. The fact that the baby expired within 24 hours does not negate the coverage for the treatment provided during that time. The claim for the newborn's intensive care expenses would be admissible under the family's floater sum insured.

While a discharge summary from a **Clinical Psychologist** is acceptable, as they are recognized under the definition of a "Mental Healthcare Professional" (Page 21, Definition 27), the prescription must come from the appropriate specialist, which in this case is a Psychiatrist.

Based on the policy, both pre-hospitalization and post-hospitalization expenses can be claimed, subject to certain conditions.

**Pre-hospitalization Expenses:**
The policy covers pre-hospitalization medical expenses for up to **30 days** before the date of admission. Since the expenses occurred 18 days before admission, they fall within this period and can be claimed.

**Post-hospitalization Expenses:**
The policy covers post-hospitalization medical expenses, including diagnostics and pharmacy costs, for up to **60 days** after the date of discharge. As the infection-related expenses were incurred 20 days after discharge, they are within the covered period and can be claimed.

**Conditions for Claiming:**
For both types of expenses, the following conditions must be met:
*   The claim for the in-patient hospitalization must be admissible and accepted by the insurance company.
*   The pre- and post-hospitalization expenses must be for the same illness or injury for which the person was hospitalized.

**Claim Submission Deadline:**
*   Documents for reimbursement of pre-hospitalization expenses must be submitted within **15 days** of the discharge date from the hospital.
*   Documents for reimbursement of post-hospitalization expenses must be submitted within **15 days** from the completion of the post-hospitalization treatment.

According to the policy, a dependent child is eligible for coverage up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.

When a dependent insured person ceases to be a Dependent (for instance, by turning 27), their coverage ends. However, the policy allows for a specific agreement to be made for the coverage to continue until the end of the policy period.

In a similar context, such as the death of an employee, the policy states that their dependents may continue to be covered until the expiry of the policy period at the option of the insured. This indicates that coverage can extend to the policy's end date even after an event that changes eligibility.

According to the Proportionate Clause (Note 1 under Clause III.A.1. In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover), if an insured person is admitted to a room with a rent exceeding the policy limit, the reimbursement for all associated medical expenses will be handled as follows:

The reimbursement/payment of all associated medical expenses incurred at the Hospital shall be effected in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent.

If a claim is partly rejected due to a lack of required documentation, the insurer will inform the insured of the deficiency. If the necessary documents are not submitted within 10 working days of the first notification, the insurer will send up to three reminders.

Should the claim be finally rejected after the resubmission of documents, the insurer must provide a written explanation for the rejection within 15 days of receiving the final documents.

To contest this final rejection, the insured person has the following course of action:

1.  **Request for Reconsideration:** Within 15 days of receiving the rejection notice, the insured may ask the insurer to reconsider the decision.
2.  **Grievance Redressal:** If unsatisfied with the outcome of the reconsideration, the insured can contact the company's grievance redressal channels:
    *   **Website:** www.uiic.co.in
    *   **Toll-free:** 1800 425 333 33
    *   **E-mail:** customercare@uiic.co.in
    *   **Courier:** Customer Care Department, Head Office, United India Insurance Co. Ltd., 24, Whites Road, Chennai, Tamil Nadu- 600014
    *   **In-person:** Approach the grievance cell at any of the company's branches.
3.  **Escalate to Grievance Officer:** If the issue remains unresolved, the insured can contact the grievance officer at customercare@uiic.co.in.
4.  **Approach the Insurance Ombudsman:** If still not satisfied, the insured may approach the office of the Insurance Ombudsman for their respective region.
5.  **Lodge a Complaint with IRDAI:** A grievance can also be filed with the IRDAI Integrated Grievance Management System at https://igms.irda.gov.in/.

For a hospital to qualify under the policy, it must meet several minimum criteria. The requirements differ based on the population of the town where the hospital is located.

**In towns with a population of less than 10,00,000 (1 million):**
*   Must have at least **10 in-patient beds**.
*   Must have qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock.
*   Must have qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock.
*   Must have a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out.
*   Must maintain daily records of patients and make them accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.

**In all other places (including metropolitan areas with a population of 1 million or more):**
*   The requirements are the same, except the hospital must have at least **15 in-patient beds**.

Based on the provided policy, here are the eligibility criteria and the process for the requested additions:

**Eligibility Criteria:**

*   **New Employee:** Must be a newly appointed employee of the policyholder.
*   **Spouse:** Must be the employee's legal spouse or life partner.
*   **Sibling:** Must be the employee's sibling, under the age of 26, and must be unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.

**Process and Documentation:**

The policyholder must submit a written request for the additions. The process requires the following:
1.  The application for cover must be accepted by the insurance company.
2.  An additional premium must be paid on a pro-rata basis for the new members.
3.  The underwriter will assess the request and may ask for additional information or documents.
4.  Once approved, the insurance company will issue an endorsement confirming the addition of the new members to the policy.

Robotic surgery for malignancies (cancer) is covered whether performed as an inpatient or as a day care procedure. The policy states that expenses for modern treatments are covered "either as in-patient or as part of day care treatment in a hospital."

The applicable sub-limit, as specified in the "Other Special Conditions" of the policy schedule, is a restriction to 50% of the Sum Insured (SI) for the 12 modern treatments as per IRDAI, which includes robotic surgery.

If the Insured Person is continuously covered without any break as defined under the applicable norms on portability stipulated by IRDAI, then the waiting period for a specific illness like knee replacement due to osteoarthritis would be reduced to the extent of the prior coverage. This exclusion applies to a list of specific diseases and procedures, including "Knee Replacement Surgery (other than caused by an Accident), Non-infectious Arthritis, Gout, Rheumatism, Osteoarthritis and Osteoporosis."

Based on the policy documents, coverage for an imported medication depends on whether it meets the criteria for "Medically Necessary Treatment" and is not classified as "Unproven/Experimental Treatment."

According to the policy:

*   **Medically Necessary Treatment** is defined as treatment that, among other criteria, "must conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India." (Page 20, Definition 27)
*   **Unproven/Experimental Treatment** is defined as "treatment, including drug experimental therapy, which is not based on established medical practice in India, is treatment experimental or unproven." (Page 20, Definition 43)
*   The policy explicitly excludes expenses for **Unproven Treatments**, which are defined as those that "lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness." (Page 25, Clause 16)

Therefore, the expense for the imported medication may be covered if it is part of a professional standard widely accepted in international medical practice and has significant medical documentation to support its use. However, if it is considered experimental or not based on established medical practice in India, it will be excluded from coverage.

If there is a deficiency in the necessary claim documents, such as providing only a generic invoice without an implant sticker, the company may, at its sole discretion, deduct the amount of the claim for which the deficiency is noted and settle the rest of the claim if it is otherwise valid.

**Required Documentation:**

*   Claim settlement advice duly certified by the other insurer.

### **Cashless Psychiatric Care for a Dependent Child**

Coverage for inpatient psychiatric care for a dependent child is available under the Mental Illness Cover (Section 3.1.14). To avail this on a cashless basis at "Harmony Wellness," the following conditions must be met:

*   **Network Hospital:** "Harmony Wellness" must be a "Mental Health Establishment" as defined in the policy and part of the insurer's network of hospitals.
*   **Medical Necessity:** Hospitalization must be for a covered mental illness and advised by a Mental Health Professional.
*   **Pre-authorization:** You must obtain pre-admission authorization from the Company/TPA. They will verify eligibility and issue a pre-authorization letter to the hospital.
*   **Dependent Child:** The policy covers dependent children from 91 days up to 18 years. A male child can be covered up to 25 years if he is a financially dependent student, and a female child is covered until she gets married.

### **Life Hardship Survival Benefit for Critical Illness**

If an Insured Person is diagnosed with one of the 11 specified critical illnesses, including cancer, a survival benefit is payable after hospital discharge. This benefit is paid only once per disease during the insured's lifetime and is not applicable for illnesses existing at the time of policy inception.

The payable amount depends on the survival period, as detailed below:

| Total amount payable | Amount payable on survival for 180 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (the first discharge date when more than one Hospitalization is involved). | Amount payable on survival for 270 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (the first discharge date when more than one Hospitalization is involved). |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **15% of Sum Insured under the Policy** | 5% of the Sum Insured | 10% of the Sum Insured |
| **25% of Sum Insured under the Policy** | 10% of the Sum Insured | 15% of the Sum Insured |

### **Required Documents for a Claim (including Cancer Diagnosis)**

For a cancer claim, you must submit the final claim with the following documents to the Company/TPA within 15 days of discharge from the hospital. The diagnosis for cancer must be supported by histological evidence of malignancy confirmed by a pathologist.

**Air Ambulance Pre-Authorization**

This cover is available only for the **Platinum Plan** and can be used once in a policy lifetime. For an accidental trauma case, the policy covers air ambulance costs up to 5% of the sum insured, provided that:
*   It is a life-threatening medical emergency requiring immediate and rapid transportation that ground transport cannot provide.
*   Necessary medical treatment is not available at the current location.
*   It is prescribed by a Medical Practitioner and is medically necessary.
*   The insured person is in India.
*   The air ambulance is duly licensed by the government.

To get pre-authorization, you must contact the Company/TPA with the relevant medical details to verify eligibility and receive an authorization letter.

**Re-issuing a Lost Policy Document**

The provided policy document does not contain information on the process for re-issuing a lost policy document.

**Waiting Period for New Dependents**

For members added during the policy term (midterm inclusion), the following waiting periods will apply starting from the date of their inclusion in the policy:
*   **30-day waiting period:** Expenses for the treatment of any illness within the first 30 days are not covered, except for claims arising from an accident (as per clause 4.3).
*   **Specified disease/procedure waiting period:** Expenses for a list of specified conditions (like hernia, cataract, joint replacement, etc.) are not covered until after a waiting period of 1, 2, or 3 years, as applicable (as per clause 4.2).
*   **Pre-existing Diseases (PED) waiting period:** Expenses for any pre-existing disease and its complications are not covered until after 36 months of continuous coverage (as per clause 4.1).

For cataract surgery, there is a specified waiting period of 2 years from the inception of the first policy. Expenses for the surgery are only covered after this period has passed.

You can request to upgrade your plan from Silver to Diamond and enhance the sum insured at the time of policy renewal. However, a plan change is only allowed if there have been no claims reported in the two immediate preceding policy periods. Similarly, an increase in the sum insured is not permitted if claims have been reported in two successive policy periods. If the sum insured is enhanced, the waiting periods will apply afresh to the enhanced portion.

### **Cashless Psychiatric Care for a Dependent Child**

Coverage for inpatient psychiatric care for a dependent child is available under the Mental Illness Cover (Section 3.1.14). To avail this on a cashless basis at "Harmony Wellness," the following conditions must be met:

*   **Network Hospital:** "Harmony Wellness" must be a "Mental Health Establishment" as defined in the policy and part of the insurer's network of hospitals.
*   **Medical Necessity:** Hospitalization must be for a covered mental illness and advised by a Mental Health Professional.
*   **Pre-authorization:** You must obtain pre-admission authorization from the Company/TPA. They will verify eligibility and issue a pre-authorization letter to the hospital.
*   **Dependent Child:** The policy covers dependent children from 91 days up to 18 years. A male child can be covered up to 25 years if he is a financially dependent student, and a female child is covered until she gets married.

### **Life Hardship Survival Benefit for Critical Illness**

If an Insured Person is diagnosed with one of the 11 specified critical illnesses, including cancer, a survival benefit is payable after hospital discharge. This benefit is paid only once per disease during the insured's lifetime and is not applicable for illnesses existing at the time of policy inception.

The payable amount depends on the survival period, as detailed below:

| Total amount payable | Amount payable on survival for 180 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (the first discharge date when more than one Hospitalization is involved). | Amount payable on survival for 270 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (the first discharge date when more than one Hospitalization is involved). |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **15% of Sum Insured under the Policy** | 5% of the Sum Insured | 10% of the Sum Insured |
| **25% of Sum Insured under the Policy** | 10% of the Sum Insured | 15% of the Sum Insured |

### **Required Documents for a Claim (including Cancer Diagnosis)**

For a cancer claim, you must submit the final claim with the following documents to the Company/TPA within 15 days of discharge from the hospital. The diagnosis for cancer must be supported by histological evidence of malignancy confirmed by a pathologist.

**Air Ambulance Pre-Authorization**

This cover is available only for the **Platinum Plan** and can be used once in a policy lifetime. For an accidental trauma case, the policy covers air ambulance costs up to 5% of the sum insured, provided that:
*   It is a life-threatening medical emergency requiring immediate and rapid transportation that ground transport cannot provide.
*   Necessary medical treatment is not available at the current location.
*   It is prescribed by a Medical Practitioner and is medically necessary.
*   The insured person is in India.

The provided policy document does not contain information on the process for re-issuing a lost policy document.

For members added during the policy term (midterm inclusion), the following waiting periods will apply starting from the date of their inclusion in the policy:
*   **30-day waiting period:** Expenses for the treatment of any illness within the first 30 days are not covered, except for claims arising from an accident (as per clause 4.3).

For cataract surgery, there is a specified waiting period of 2 years from the inception of the first policy. Expenses for the surgery are only covered after this period has passed.

If the sum insured is enhanced, the waiting periods will apply afresh to the enhanced portion.

questions: What is my flight number?
answers:
To find your flight number, you must follow these steps:

1.  **Get the city name:** Call the API endpoint `GET https://register.hackrx.in/submissions/myFavouriteCity`.

2.  **Decode the city:** Use the tables in the document to find the landmark associated with the city name you received from the API. For example, if the city is "Chennai", the corresponding landmark is "Charminar".

3.  **Choose your flight path:** Based on the landmark you identified, call the correct API endpoint from the list below:
    *   **If the landmark is "Gateway of India"**, call: `GET https://register.hackrx.in/teams/public/flights/getFirstCityFlightNumber`
    *   **If the landmark is "Taj Mahal"**, call: `GET https://register.hackrx.in/teams/public/flights/getSecondCityFlightNumber`
    *   **If the landmark is "Eiffel Tower"**, call: `GET https://register.hackrx.in/teams/public/flights/getThirdCityFlightNumber`
    *   **If the landmark is "Big Ben"**, call: `GET https://register.hackrx.in/teams/public/flights/getFourthCityFlightNumber`
    *   **For all other landmarks**, call: `GET https://register.hackrx.in/teams/public/flights/getFifthCityFlightNumber`

The response from calling the correct endpoint in step 3 will be your final flight number.

questions: Explain this document to me ie summarize its full contents
answers: This document, titled "Sample PDF Document" by Robert Maron and Grzegorz Grudziński, serves as a template and guide for creating documents using LaTeX and pdfLaTeX. It covers three main topics: How to compile a .tex file to a .pdf file: This section lists the required tools, including pdflatex , acroread , ghostscript , and efax . It then provides a step-by-step guide on how to use these tools to compile the source files. How to write a document: This part explains how to structure a document by using a main .tex file and including individual chapters from separate files. It also emphasizes the necessity of spell-checking. LaTeX and pdfLaTeX capabilities: The document provides an overview of the functionalities of LaTeX and pdfLaTeX. It includes examples of various formatting options such as: Hyperlinks Different types of dashes National and reserved characters Mathematical equations and symbols A variety of fonts and sizes, from "tiny" to "Huge".

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer if the total claim for the same hospitalization has already been approved and settled by HDFC. The policy covers medical expenses up to the sum insured per policy, and claims for the same hospitalization cannot be split between insurers beyond the actual expenses incurred. If your sum insured with HDFC is sufficient and the claim is settled, you cannot claim the same expenses again with another insurer.
